title: Can anyone identify this font?
content:
Hey,

Could anyone please help me identify this font?

Thanks,  
Robyn

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013112135im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Screen%20Shot%202013-06-21%20at%2011_5093.12.35.png)
author: robski

comments.content:
Doesn't look like a font to me, more a custom job (and a bad one). It may have started with a contrasted flare serif, removing some serifs and rebuilding some letters (/G?)  
Same vein, better design to me: [Goldenbook](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013112135/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/marksimonson/goldenbook), [Felix Ttiling](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013112135/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/felix-titling), [Shango](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013112135/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/castletype/shango), [Danmark](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013112135/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/urw/danmark), [Clarice](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013112135/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/garagefonts/clarice), [Seta Reta](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013112135/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/seta-reta-nf)

A font that is the victim of this serif clipping treatment is sometimes called demi-serif. It was a fad a few years ago -- some stores even redid their logos -- but the attraction of the procedure seems to have waned. For fonts that look like this try searches for demi-serif and semi-serif. Might even find one that matches.  
Don
